title: 108_s501
content:
The "Gifted and Talented Students Education Act of 2003" establishes a grant program for gifted and talented students under Chapter B. This program includes authorized activities for supporting these students. The "Gifted and Talented Students Education Act of 2003" recognizes the need to provide specialized services for gifted and talented students from diverse backgrounds, including those with disabilities or English as a second language. Elementary school gifted students have already mastered a significant portion of the curriculum before the school year begins. Many students from diverse backgrounds, including those with limited English proficiency, disabilities, and diverse cultural backgrounds, are historically underrepresented in gifted education programs. Elementary school students who are gifted and talented have already mastered a significant portion of the curriculum before the school year begins. However, teachers often lack training on meeting the needs of gifted and talented students. To address the needs of diverse students, including those with limited English proficiency, disabilities, and diverse backgrounds, public schools must provide gifted education programs. While some students can access private programs, many high-ability students rely on public school services. Qualified professionals in public schools are essential to offer equal educational opportunities. Parents and families play a crucial role as partners in education. Gifted education programs in public schools are crucial for providing equal educational opportunities to high-ability students. Parents and families are essential partners in developing appropriate services for gifted students. Currently, there is no federal requirement to identify or serve the approximately 3,000,000 gifted and talented students in the nation. To address the educational, social, and emotional needs of gifted and talented students, it is crucial to have consistent strategies and resources in place at the state and local levels. Currently, there is no federal mandate to support the 3,000,000 gifted students nationwide, leading to disparities in services due to varying state laws and funding mechanisms. It is essential for the future economic and national security of the United States to ensure that all highly capable students achieve at higher levels. The funding, identification, and accountability mechanisms for gifted and talented students vary widely, leading to disparities in services. It is crucial for the future economic and national security of the United States to ensure that highly capable students achieve at higher levels in order to secure the nation's position in the world. In the United States, performance in physics and advanced mathematics on the TIMSS study was among the lowest globally. Funding for challenging programs for gifted students was minimal, with less than 2 cents out of every $100 spent on education allocated for this purpose. The Secretary may award competitive grants to states for amounts between $7,500,000 and $57,500,000 under the program authorization. The Secretary may award competitive grants to states for developing or expanding gifted and talented education programs, with funding amounts ranging from $7,500,000 to $57,500,000. The Secretary may award grants to State educational agencies to enable them to provide direct educational services and materials for developing or expanding gifted and talented education programs. Grant funds can be used for various authorized activities, including providing curriculum for gifted students. Grant funds provided under this chapter can be used for activities such as providing direct educational services and materials to gifted and talented students, including curriculum compacting, modified curriculum, acceleration, independent study, and dual enrollment. However, funds cannot be used for course work provided through emerging technologies. Grant funds provided under this chapter can be used for activities like developing curriculum packages, compensating distance-learning educators, and other relevant activities. However, funds cannot be used for purchasing or upgrading technological hardware. Additionally, a State educational agency receiving a grant under this chapter is limited to using no more than 10 percent of the funds for dissemination of general program information, providing technical assistance, and monitoring and evaluation of programs and activities. The State educational agency can use grant funds for activities such as curriculum development, compensating educators, and creating a gifted education advisory board. Up to 50% of the funds can be used for administrative costs. "SEC. 5467A. ALLOTMENTS TO STATES." The Secretary reserves funds for programs in schools operated or funded by the Bureau of Indian Affairs. The remaining amount is allotted to states based on their populations of individuals aged 5 through 17. No state may receive less than \1/2\ of 1 percent. The Secretary allocates funds to states based on their populations of individuals aged 5 through 17. States must receive a minimum grant amount of \1/2\ of 1 percent. If a state does not apply for funding, the Secretary reallocates the amount to other states. The Secretary allocates funds to states based on their populations of individuals aged 5 through 17, with a minimum grant amount requirement. If a state does not apply for funding, the Secretary reallocates the amount to other states. To be eligible for a grant under this chapter, a State educational agency must submit an application to the Secretary with assurances that funds will support gifted and talented students from diverse backgrounds, with grants also given to local educational agencies on a competitive basis. The State educational agency must use funds to support gifted and talented students, provide matching funds, and develop program assessment models. The State educational agency must provide matching funds equal to at least 10 percent of the grant funds received and develop program assessment models for accountability and effectiveness. The Secretary will approve a State's application if it meets the requirements of this section. SEC. 5467C requires State educational agencies to allocate at least 90% of funds to local educational agencies through a competitive process for authorized activities. Grants must meet the needs of students. To be eligible for a grant under this chapter, a local educational agency must submit an application to the State educational agency. The application must include assurances that funds will support gifted and talented students from diverse backgrounds, a plan to meet their educational needs, and a commitment to use funds for this purpose. The local educational agency must submit an application to the State educational agency for a grant under this chapter. The application should include assurances that funds will support gifted and talented students, a plan to meet their educational needs, and a commitment to use funds for this purpose. Additionally, the agency must describe how they will meet the educational needs of gifted and talented students, including training personnel, and ensure that funds will supplement, not supplant, existing resources for these students. ``Beginning 1 year after enactment, State educational agencies must submit annual reports to the Secretary detailing the number of students served and activities supported with funds under this chapter. Recipients of funds can serve gifted students alongside those with similar needs. Private school children and teachers can also participate in the program.`` ``SEC. 5467F. CONSTRUCTION.

    Recipients of funds under this chapter can serve gifted and talented students alongside those with similar educational needs in appropriate settings.

SEC. 5467G. PARTICIPATION OF PRIVATE SCHOOL CHILDREN AND TEACHERS.

    The Secretary must ensure equitable participation of students and teachers from private nonprofit schools in grants and professional development programs.

SEC. 5467H. DEFINITIONS.`` The term 'gifted and talented' is defined under applicable State law or by the State educational agency if no State law exists. The term 'State' refers to each of the 50 states, the District of Columbia, and the Commonwealth of Puerto Rico. If a State does not have a law defining 'gifted and talented,' the term is defined as per section 9101. Authorization of Appropriations for the Jacob K. Javits Gifted and Talented Students Education Program is set at $170,000,000 annually from 2004 to 2010. $7,500,000 is allocated for Chapter A, with the remainder for Chapter 2. Technical and conforming amendments are made to the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965. Technical and conforming amendments are made to the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965, specifically to Subpart 6 of part D of title V. This includes renaming the subpart to "Chapter A--Jacob K. Javits Gifted and Talented Students Education Program" and adjusting references from "this part" to "this chapter." Additionally, subsections in section 5464 are reorganized.
